column1: Edmonds is a city in Snohomish County
column3: United States. It is located in the southwest corner of the county
column4: facing Puget Sound and the Olympic Mountains to the west. The city is part of the Seattle metropolitan area and is located 15 miles (24 km) north of Seattle and 18 miles (29 km) southwest of Everett. With a population of 39
column6: Edmonds is the third most populous city in the county. The estimated population in 2019 was 42

column1: Edmonds was established in 1876 by logger George Brackett
column2: who bought the land claim of an earlier settler. It was incorporated as a city in 1890
column3: shortly before the arrival of the Great Northern Railway. Early residents of the city were employed by the shingle mills and logging companies that operated in the area until the 1950s. The hills surrounding Edmonds were developed into suburban bedroom communities in the mid-to-late 20th century and subsequently annexed into the city. Edmonds is a regional hub for the arts
column6: and major annual festivals within the city's downtown area.

column1: The city is connected to nearby areas by two state highways and the state ferry system
column2: which operates a ferry route to Kingston on the Kitsap Peninsula. Public transit service in Edmonds is centered around the downtown train station
column3: served by Amtrak and Sounder commuter trains
column4: and includes several Community Transit bus routes that travel through outlying neighborhoods.

column2: the Edmonds area was inhabited by the Suquamish tribe
column3: who foraged and fished near the flat beach forming modern-day downtown. No archaeological evidence of a permanent settlement in Edmonds has been found
column4: despite claims that a fishing village had existed near the modern-day downtown.An exploratory expedition of Puget Sound led by Charles Wilkes charted the Edmonds area in 1841
column5: naming "Point Edmund" (now Point Edwards) to the southwest of the modern-day downtown. A 147-acre (59 ha) land claim for the area was filed by Pleasant Ewell in 1866 and was sold to various landowners before being eventually purchased by Canadian-born logger George Brackett in 1872 for $650. Brackett had allegedly found the future site of Edmonds in 1870 while searching for potential logging areas on his canoe
column6: which was blown ashore during a storm. Brackett and his family moved from Ballard to Point Edmund in 1876
column7: intent on creating a town. He drained a marshland near the waterfront and began logging the area
column8: then known as "Brackett's Landing". Additional settlers arrived over the next few years
column9: necessitating the construction of a wharf and general store by 1881. In 1884

Brackett was elected as the town's mayor for several months and the new town council passed ordinances to regulate or ban saloons

column14: the destroyed buildings were bought by a city councilman and was replaced by a two-story concrete building.The first automobile owned by an Edmonds resident arrived in 1911 and was followed by the completion of the North Trunk Road through modern-day Lynnwood. A branch road to Edmonds was completed in 1915 and stagecoach lines were extended to the city. Automobile ferry service began in 1923

column20: damaging several buildings on the same block of Main Street as the 1909 fire. Despite the increasing scarcity of local timber
column21: the sawmills on the Edmonds waterfront remained the city's main industry in the 1920s. During the Great Depression

column2: including an aluminum fabricator and an asphalt refinery at the Unocal terminal. The now vacated waterfront was redeveloped under the direction of the Port of Edmonds

column2: the number of businesses in downtown Edmonds declined as suburban shopping centers lured away customers. After a number of buildings in the downtown area were demolished and replaced with condominiums and office buildings
column3: a movement to preserve and restore historic buildings emerged with the support of the city government. The "Main Street Project"
column5: restored empty storefronts and attracted restaurants to the city in the late 1980s
column6: fueling a downtown revival. Portions of the waterfront were acquired by the city and redeveloped into a public beach
column8: and a public fishing pier was opened in 1979 as the first saltwater fishing pier in the state. Edmonds celebrated its centennial in 1990 with a series of events and the dedication of the Centennial Plaza. Several neighborhoods in southern Edmonds were annexed between 1995 and 1997
column9: forming the city's southern boundary at the King County line.The Point Edwards oil terminal on the city's waterfront was closed by Unocal in 1991 and the 53-acre (21 ha) site was sought by Edmonds and Snohomish County for redevelopment. The city favored the construction of a new multimodal transportation hub at the site
column10: including a ferry terminal and commuter rail station
column11: while the county proposed the construction of a sewage treatment plant to be used by King and Snohomish counties. The sewage treatment plant was opposed by the city government and citizen groups
column12: and was ultimately moved to an alternative site near Woodinville in 2003. The transportation plan was put on hold after costs increased and the state ferry system diverted funding to other projects. The hilltop portion of the site was cleaned up in the 2000s and redeveloped into condominiums that opened between 2007 and 2008.

column1: Edmonds is located in the southwest corner of Snohomish County in Western Washington
column2: and is considered a suburb of Seattle

column7: and Lund's Gulch. The unincorporated area of Esperance

column15: and the State Route 99 corridor at its east end. The downtown area and "bowl" has views of Puget Sound and the Olympic Mountains. The city has several outlying suburban neighborhood with their own commercial centers

column1: Edmonds operates as a non-charter code city under a mayor–council government
column2: with an elected mayor and a seven-member city council. The mayor is elected to a four-year term and is a nonpartisan position. Former councilmember Mike Nelson was elected as mayor in 2019
column3: succeeding two-term mayor Dave Earling. The city council's seven members are elected at-large to four-year terms and serve as the legislative body that establishes city policy.The municipal government employs 224 people full-time and operates on an annual budget of $98 million that is mostly funded by property and retail sales taxes. The budget funds the city's various departments
column8: and emergency services.At the federal level
column9: Edmonds has been part of the 7th congressional district since 2012
column10: represented by Democrat Pramila Jayapal of Seattle. Prior to the 2012 redistricting in Washington
column11: Edmonds was part of the 1st congressional district
column12: represented by Jay Inslee. At the state level
column13: the city is divided between the 21st and 32nd legislative districts. The 21st district is represented by senator Marko Liias and representatives Strom Peterson and Lillian Ortiz-Self; the 32nd district is represented by senator Maralyn Chase
column14: and representatives Cindy Ryu and Ruth Kagi. Edmonds is wholly part of the Snohomish County Council's 3rd district
column15: represented by former Lynnwood city councilwoman Stephanie Wright since her appointment in 2010.

column1: Edmonds is considered a major hub for the arts in Snohomish County
column2: with a dozen galleries and other arts facilities. The city government established the Edmonds Art Commission in 1975 and developed its public arts program in the following decades. The city has a collection of 35 outdoor art installations
column3: 22 flower pole structures
column4: and maintains several facilities dedicated to various arts. One of its initiatives was the 1979 conversion of the former Edmonds High School building into the Frances Anderson Cultural and Leisure Center
column10: and recreational sports leagues. The city also renovated the high school auditorium into the Edmonds Center for the Arts in 2006
column11: serving as the home of theatrical performances
column14: and films.Edmonds has hosted the annual Edmonds Arts Festival since 1957
column15: with three days of art exhibitions and performances over Father's Day weekend in June. The festival is one of the largest in the Pacific Northwest
column18: and has 200 participating artists with booths along Main Street and at the Frances Anderson Center. The Cascadia Art Museum opened in 2015 at the location of a former grocery store in downtown Edmonds and focuses on regional Northwest art. Downtown Edmonds also has a single-screen movie theater that was built in the 1920s and remains independently owned and operated.In addition to the visual arts
column19: Edmonds has several active performing arts organizations. The Driftwood Players host year-round theatrical performances at the Wade James Theatre near Yost Park
column20: while the Phoenix Theatre is based at Firdale Village. The city also hosts the annual Edmonds Jazz Connection over Memorial Day weekend in late May
column21: with several school jazz groups and professional performers. In November 2018
column22: Edmonds was designated as the first creative district in Washington by ArtsWA
column23: the state art agency.One of the city's main landmarks is a small fountain located at the center of a roundabout on Main Street. The first fountain
column24: which included a twisted sculpture at its center
column25: was installed in 1973 and drew criticism from local residents and merchants for its ugliness. It was destroyed in 1998 by a drunk driver and replaced with a temporary gazebo
column26: which had been used as a prop for a TV series. The gazebo was popular and replaced with a bronze structure in 2000
column27: which was later destroyed by a driver five years later. The gazebo was rebuilt in 2006 and has remained since.Edmonds is home to a weekly farmers' market that runs from June to October on Saturdays and is sponsored by the Edmonds–South Snohomish County Historical Society. The city also has several annual summer festivals
column28: including the Edmonds Waterfront Festival in early June
column29: the Edmonds Art Festival in mid-June
column30: the Edmonds in Bloom garden festival in July
column31: and the Taste of Edmonds food festival in August.

column1: Edmonds was served by one weekly newspaper
column3: for most of the 20th century. The newspaper was formed by the merger of two rival publications in 1910 and ran until 1982
column4: when it was replaced by an Edmonds section in The Enterprise
column5: a regional newspaper based in Lynnwood. Today
column6: Edmonds is served by The Everett Herald and The Seattle Times. Since 1986
column7: the Edmonds Beacon has published a free weekly newspaper alongside sister papers in Mukilteo and Mill Creek. Edmonds is also home to a local blog
column9: that has covered city affairs since 2009 and is an affiliate of The Seattle Times.The Edmonds library was established in 1901 and moved into a permanent building funded by philanthropist Andrew Carnegie in 1911. The Carnegie Library served as a dual library and city hall until 1962
column10: when a new civic center opened. Edmonds was annexed into the Sno-Isle Libraries system and is served by a 20
column12: 900 m2) library building that was opened in 1982.

column1: Edmonds has 23 city parks with 189 acres (76 ha) of open and preserved space
column2: along with several facilities shared with the school district and the county government
column3: totaling 560 acres (230 ha). Downtown Edmonds has several major parks
column4: including the public beach at Brackett's Landing on both sides of the ferry terminal
column6: and the future Civic Field. A small 9/11 memorial
column7: including a steel beam from the World Trade Center
column8: is located at a fire station near downtown Edmonds and was dedicated in 2015.In addition to the neighborhood and community parks in Edmonds
column9: the city also maintains dog parks
column12: and a skate park. Edmonds Stadium
column13: which was home to high school sports and minor league football and soccer teams (including the North Sound SeaWolves)
column14: was opened in 1937 and closed in 2017. The Edmonds senior center opened in the 1960s and is planned to be replaced by a new building
column16: in 2020.The city also has several urban forests and natural reserves
column17: which preserve the original vegetation of the area and provide hiking and walking trails. Edmonds Marsh Park
column18: on 28 acres (11 ha) south of downtown
column19: preserves one of the few remaining saltwater marshes in the state and is home to 225 species of bird and several walking trails. The largest wooded space in the city is the county-run Southwest County Park
column20: with 120 acres (49 ha) of land along Olympic View Drive at the north end of the city.The Port of Edmonds maintains the city's public marina
column21: which has 890 slips and is one of the largest in the Puget Sound region. The marina is dredged to a depth of 13 feet (4.0 m) and located southwest of downtown Edmonds. Further north and offshore from Brackett's Landing
column22: the city also maintains a 27-acre (11 ha) marine park called the Edmonds Underwater Park
column23: which was developed primarily for scuba diving. The park attracts 25
column24: 000 visitors annually and is one of the most popular diving spots in the state. The park features man-made reefs

column1: Edmonds' sole entry on the National Register of Historic Places
column3: was added in 1973 and currently houses the Edmonds Historical Museum
column4: a local museum operated by the Edmonds–South Snohomish County Historical Society.The city government created its own historical commission in 2007 and now maintains a separate register of historic places with 18 buildings. The city's historic designation
column6: comes without design or building restrictions and primarily includes historic homes and businesses.

column1: Edmonds has one sister city relationship
column2: established in 1988 with Hekinan in Japan's Aichi Prefecture. The relationship is commemorated with a totem pole and plaque on the waterfront. Three times per year
column3: the two cities send visiting delegations
column5: in addition to regularly exchanging gifts and holiday greetings.

column1: Edmonds is wholly within the boundaries of the Edmonds School District
column3: Mountlake Terrace
column4: and Woodway. The city is home to Edmonds Woodway High School
column5: of the district's five high schools
column6: which was formed in 1990 after the merger of Edmonds and Woodway and moved in 1998 to a new campus east of the city. The high school has 1
column7: 800 students and is one of the top schools in the state and hosts an IB Diploma Programme. The school district also operates an alternative high school
column11: and two combined elementary–middle schools within Edmonds city limits.Edmonds is located near the campus of Edmonds College
column12: which actually lies within Lynnwood city limits. The city was formerly home to the private Puget Sound Christian College
column13: which operated from 1977 to 2001 at the former Edmonds High School building (now the Edmonds Center for the Arts). Edmonds is also home to several private schools

column1: Edmonds is served by several modes of transportation that converge in the downtown area
column3: railroads
column5: and buses. The city's ferry terminal is located at the west end of Main Street at Brackett's Landing Park and is served by a ferry route to Kingston on the Kitsap Peninsula. From 1979 to 1980
column6: Washington State Ferries also ran ferries to Port Townsend during repairs to the Hood Canal Bridge. The Edmonds train station lies a block southwest of the terminal and is served by Amtrak's intercity Cascades and Empire Builder trains as well as Sound Transit's Sounder commuter train. These trains operate on the BNSF Railway
column7: which runs along the Edmonds waterfront and is primarily used for freight transport. Two state highways
column9: connect the downtown area to eastern Edmonds and other points in southern Snohomish County and northern King County. An additional state highway
column11: runs north–south in eastern Edmonds and connects the city's commercial district to Seattle and Everett.Public transportation in Edmonds is provided by Community Transit
column12: which serves most of Snohomish County and covers 74 percent of Edmonds residents. Community Transit's local buses run on major streets and connect downtown Edmonds to transit hubs at Aurora Village
column14: and Edmonds Community College. It also operates Swift on State Route 99
column15: a bus rapid transit service connecting Aurora Village and Everett. Community Transit also operates three commuter routes that run from park and ride lots in Edmonds to Downtown Seattle and the University District.

column1: Electric power in Edmonds is provided by the Snohomish County Public Utility District (PUD)
column2: a consumer-owned public utility that serves all of Snohomish County. In 2017
column3: the city signed a clean energy pledge that would mandate the use of renewable energy sources to generate all of its electricity by 2025. Puget Sound Energy provides natural gas service to the city's residents and businesses.The city's municipal tap water is provided by the Alderwood Water District
column4: which sources its water from Everett's Spada Lake Reservoir. The city government maintains its own sanitary sewer and wastewater treatment services
column5: including a treatment plant in downtown; wastewater is also sent to the regional Brightwater plant near Maltby
column6: which was originally planned to be built in Edmonds. Disposal of garbage
column8: and yard waste is contracted by the city government to three private companies serving different areas of Edmonds.

column1: Edmonds is home to one general hospital
column2: a branch of the Swedish Medical Center
column3: which is located on State Route 99. It was established in 1964 and was run independently until the hospital was acquired by Swedish in 2010. The hospital sits at the center of a district of medical and professional services offices along State Route 99.
